examples/rss.php
Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 <?php
00002 /**
00003  * Using QueryPath to Generate an RSS feed.
00004  *
00005  * This file contains an example of how QueryPath can be used
00006  * to generate an RSS feed.
00007  *
00008  * It uses two stubs -- one for the main RSS file, and one for an RSS entry --
00009  * and it merges data into the stubs.
00010  *
00011  * The method exhibited here is one of the more primitive ways of templating 
00012  * information. See the {@link techniques.php techniques} example for multiple
00013  * methods of looping. An even more advanced method would be to use the 
00014  * {@link QPTPL} library. 
00015  *
00016  * 
00017  * @author M Butcher <matt@aleph-null.tv>
00018  * @license LGPL The GNU Lesser GPL (LGPL) or an MIT-like license.
00019  */
00020  
00021 require_once '../src/QueryPath/QueryPath.php';
00022 
00023 // This is the stub RSS document.
00024 $rss_stub ='<?xml version="1.0"?>
00025 <rss version="2.0" 
00026   xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
00027   <channel>
00028    <title></title>
00029    <link></link>
00030    <description></description>
00031    <language>en</language>
00032    <generator>QueryPath</generator>
00033    </channel>
00034 </rss>
00035 ';
00036 
00037 // This is the stub RSS element.
00038 $rss_item_stub = '<?xml version="1.0"?>
00039 <item>
00040   <title>Untitled</title>
00041   <link></link>
00042   <description>
00043   </description>
00044   <comments></comments>
00045   <category></category>
00046   <pubDate></pubDate>
00047   <guid isPermaLink="false"></guid>
00048 </item>';
00049 
00050 // Here are some dummy items. For the same of 
00051 // simplicity, we are just using a nested array. Of
00052 // course, this could be a database lookup or whatever.
00053 $items = array(
00054   array(
00055     'title' => 'Item 1',
00056     'link' => 'http://example.com/item1',
00057     'description' => '<strong>This has embedded <em>HTML</em></strong>',
00058     'comments' => 'http://example.com/item1/comments',
00059     'category' => 'Some Term',
00060     'pubDate' => date('r'),
00061     'guid' => '123456-789',
00062   ),
00063   array(
00064     'title' => 'Item 2',
00065     'link' => 'http://example.com/item2',
00066     'description' => '<strong>This has embedded <em>HTML</em></strong>',
00067     'comments' => 'http://example.com/item2/comments',
00068     'category' => 'Some Other Term',
00069     'pubDate' => date('r'),
00070     'guid' => '123456-790',
00071   ),
00072 );
00073 
00074 // The main QueryPath, which holds the channel.
00075 $qp = qp($rss_stub, 'title')
00076   ->text('A QueryPath RSS Feed')
00077   ->next('link')->text('http://example.com')
00078   ->next('description')->text('QueryPath: Find your way.')
00079   ->parent();
00080 
00081 // For each element in the array above, we create a new 
00082 // QueryPath and then populate the XML fragment with data.
00083 foreach ($items as $item) {
00084   
00085   // Begin with the stub RSS item, with title currently selected.
00086   $qpi = qp($rss_item_stub, 'title')
00087     // Add a title.
00088     ->text($item['title']) 
00089     // Add a link. Note that we are giving no args to next() for the
00090     // sake of simplicity.
00091     ->next()->text($item['link'])
00092     // Go to next element and add a description. Note that the text()
00093     // call will automatically encode HTML. < will become &lt; and so on.
00094     ->next()->text($item['description'])
00095     // Go on down the list...
00096     ->next()->text($item['comments'])
00097     ->next()->text($item['category'])
00098     ->next()->text($item['pubDate'])
00099     ->next()->text($item['guid']);
00100     
00101   // Now we append it.
00102   $qp->append($qpi->top());
00103 }
00104 
00105 // If we were running this on a server, we would need to set the content
00106 // type:
00107 // header('Content-Type: application/rss+xml');
00108 
00109 // Write the outpt as XML.
00110 $qp->writeXML();
00111 ?>
